name: Vietnam
takeaway: Contemporary Sino-Vietnamese relations are determined by millenia long history of mutual conflict and animosity on the one hand, and the relatively recently established affiliation to the communist ideology on the other. Vietnam perceives China as a security threat, which is also one of the reasons why the Vietnamese military operates on Soviet/Russian technology. Since the Ukrainian conflict, there has been a clear tendency on the Vietnamese side to reach out to the West in respect to modern military technologies. At the same time, Vietnamese and Chinese politburos act as the closest of friends.

The Vietnamese government often faces challenges very similar to the Chinese government in terms of human rights or freedom of speech violations and authoritarianism in genneral. On the surface, it might seem that Vietnam follows the lead and example of China. However, Vietnam is merely trying to keep its own citizens at bay as any criticism of China might be drawn back to the authoritarian Vietnamese government.

The wider public should understand the complexity of Sino-Vietnamese relations by looking further back into history, past the origins of the communist ideology. Despite the ideological, political and most importantly economic influence of China over Vietnam, the Vietnamese general public regards China with suspicion or even disdain.
description-1: In 2023, Vietnam had a GDP per capita of US$4,347 and a total population of 100.03 million people.
description-2: Vietnam established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1950. Vietnam was ranked 174th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Not Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 19/100.

Media.evidence: In the official list of the Organization of the World Association of Chinese Mass Communication Media, where all affiliated media organizations of World Chinese Media are listed, there are no affiliated media organizations in Vietnam listed.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Ho Chi Minh City Television (HTV), the second largest television network in Vietnam, is listed as a member of Belt and Road News Alliance on it's official website. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Few" and "Significant" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence:
"(1) On the occasion of the 10th anniversary of the Belt and Road Initiative, representatives of three mainstream media from Vietnam came to China's Yunnan to jointly cover the exchanges and cooperation between China and Vietnam with their Chinese peers. Although there is no evidence that this was paid by PRC, since there is no mention of the event in Vietnamese media outlets, it is very likely that it was paid by PRC for propagandistic reasons.

(2) On June 28, 2023, the CCP’s official mouthpiece, People’s Daily, hosted the fourth annual joint regional media summits, the Mekong-Lancang Cooperation Media Summit (Lancang Jiang Meigong He Hezuo Meiti Fenghui; 澜沧–江湄公河合作媒体峰会). Important Vietnamese media officials and journalists took part (3). 

Therefore, this Indicator deserves an ""Few"" and ""Significant"" rating."

The workshop and the trip to China will be arranged by the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Media Summit, which is being hosted by Chinese media and includes media outlets from China, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence:
We found an influencer that goes by the name Anh Nguyen with 8000+ followers. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
The workshop and the trip to China will be arranged by the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Media Summit, which is being hosted by Chinese media and includes media outlets from China, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam.

Media.evidence:
"China Radio International (CRI) is the primary PRC state-run media outlet. Vietnamese-language news is available on CRI’s Vietnamese website (Đài Phát thanh Quốc té Trung Quốc) and Facebook page.

Beibu Gulf Online broadcasts in Vietnamese. Beibu Gulf Online was jointly formed by CRI and Guangxi Foreign Broadcasting Station. According to Chinese media, ""Beibu Gulf Online"" (BBRTV.com) is a network-oriented new media dedicated to ASEAN countries.

Xinhua does not have a Vietnamese stand-alone website, but it is active on Twitter, where tweets appear in Vietnamese, with 49,800 followers.

Therefore, this Indicator deserves an ""Few"" and ""Insignificant"" rating."
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There are some Chinese shareholders in VNG such as Tenacious Bulldog Holding Ltd, Prosperous Prince Enterprises Ltd., and Shen Hao (link 1). Rumor says that frist two mentioned companies are connected to Tencent Holding Ltd., a Chinese multinational technology conglomerate headquartered in Shenzhen. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: According to some media experts, China has been mostly failing to influence Vietnamese media space due to the fact that Vietnamese media are under strict control of the Vietnamese government. Moreover, the general public is suspicious of news coming from China due to the problematic relations between the two countries going deep into the history.
Media.note: This Indicator measures whether local media outlets broadcast news, video clips, or other contents provided by PRC state-fund media (content-sharing agreements). The phenomenon can be observed via footages of content pieces. Therefore, press statement from PRC governmental agencies do not fall into the caterory of contents provided by PRC state-fund media.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There are journalists who have had pressure exerted on them by Vietnam itself. Writing for independent media channels such as BBC Vietnamese is disapproved by the Vietnamese government, it can lead to various problems and even incarceration in extreme cases. Due to the close ties between the Vietnamese and Chinese Communist parties, it is possible that the pressure on these Vietnamese journalists can extend to China.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There are a few Vietnamese media outlets that refer to China in this way. It is the language of the Communist party and ideology. Vietnam is a socialist country and the ties between the two Communist parties are strong. However, the attitude of the general public does not necessarily reflect that. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Regarding Taiwan, a clear statement mentioned in a Joint Declaraion after Xi Jinping's visit to Vietnam in December 2023: "Vietnam reaffirms its consistency in carrying out “One China” policy by recognising Taiwan as an inseparable part of the Chinese territory (...)". Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.

Foreign Policy.evidence:
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has repeatedly opposed the PRC’s territorial claim to the South China Sea. Vietnam also prohibits the propagation of products and prints that include China's ""nine-dash line"" map, which, according to the foreign ministry, falsely lays claim to Vietnamese territory. 

Although without naming the PRC, in his speech at the 78th session of the UN General Assembly in New York (Sep 2023), Prime Minister of Vietnam claimed: “It is also necessary to exercise restraint and refrain from unilateral actions and address disputes and differences by peaceful means, including diplomatic and legal processes.” 

Therefore, the Index country has rejected the PRC’s territorial claim and the Indicator warrants a 0 score.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: No evidence can be found of the Index country taking a definitive position regarding this Indicator. Therefore, the Index country has remained silent regarding the PRC’s treatment of its Uyghur population and the Indicator warrants a 2 score.

Academia.evidence:
At the moment, there is no evidence of research partnerships with PRC connected entities. However, there has been a mention of Vietnam–China step up cooperation in military scientific research (1). In the joint statement following Xi Jinping's official state visit to Vietnam (2), the intention to cooperate in several research areas (military, transport, agriculture, management of marine and island environments) has been mentioned.
The University of Transport and Communications (UTC) organized a cooperation signing ceremony with Huawei Technologies (Vietnam) Co. Ltd. under Huawei Group.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Yes, Chinese is taught as a foreign language from 3th to 12th grades. But Vietnam does not receive free educational books and teachers from PRC; textbooks used in the Chinese language curriculum in schools in Vietnam must conform to Vietnam’s official policy, thus, Chinese language books that contain China’s claims in the South China Sea are banned in Vietnam.

Given that the "Thousand Talents Plan" and several related initiatives have been combined into the "Overseas High-Level Talent Recruitment Program (高端外国专家引进计划)", I'm hoping the following URLs may serve as the supporting evidence.

Academia.evidence: Although there is no report on the Internet about a specific case, Vietnamese scholars and academics are aware that they may be harassed and punished if they are too critical of China, especially in sensitive issues related to China’s “core interests”. There is self-censorship among Vietnamese academics about this. Thus, although there may not be any specific case, the pressure is real and PRC punishment serves as deterrent.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Vietnam is governed by a single party authoritarian political system. Elections take place regularly but the candidates are nominated by the Communist party and no real political competition exists. Therefore, political campaigns require no funding or donations from third parties.

Domestic Politics.evidence: This indicator is irrelevant in the Vietnamese context as Vietnam is a single party political system. Political candidates are selected within the Communist party, and therefore there is no need for political fundraising.)
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by

Domestic Politics.evidence:
As Vietnam and China have been quarreling about the possession of Paracel and Spratly Islands for decades. Vietnam claims power over both archipelagos based on the 1982 UNCLOS declaration. China is building structures on islands that the UNCLOS declaration recognizes as Vietnamese. Vietnam deems this structures illegal and also destabilizing the balance in the region.
According to Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson: ""China was the first to discover, name, develop and manage these islands and archipelagos, and continue to exercise sovereign jurisdiction over them.China always opposes relevant countries' illegal claims on China's territory and will continue to firmly safeguard its sovereignty.""
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: They have done that but not out of the sense of admiration towards China but because the Vietnamese government is driven by the same ideology, the Vietnamese Communist party holds all the political power and human rights are being denied in Vietnam as well.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Politicians and government employees in Vietnam are usually appointed by the Communist party so this kind of political plotting seems rather unlikely. However, this is not to say that such practices do not exist in Vietnam. They do exist but they are utilized by the Vietnamese establishment itself.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: As Vietnam and China operate on the same ideology, the Communist party holds complete political power and both countries tend to suppress human rights or freedom of speech, any criticism of these issues in China is considered dangerous by the Vietnamese government. However, we must understood that the suppression of criticism towards China is not caused by a sense of admiration or kowtowing but by the struggle of the Vietnamese CP to stay in power.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence:
The Hoa ethnic minority (Huárén 華人) living mainly in the South of Vietnam totalling approximately 800 thousand individuals immigrated into Vietnam prior to the 19th century. They use their own dialect of Chinese in addition to their Vietnamese mother tongue and many of them are literate in the Chinese script. They also retain many aspects of the Chinese culture such as cuisine and customs. However, they mostly have single citizenship and they identify as Vietnamese.
The Chinese Embassy in Vietnam holds the 2024 Lunar New Year events.

This choice “More than a few, but insignificant" reflects that PRC-connected entities do have a presence in distributing entertainment products and services in Vietnam, but the impact or influence of these distributions can still be considered limited or not highly impactful at this point. While PRC content is available and accessible through various platforms and devices, it does not dominate the market or significantly shift local consumption patterns and preferences.

Military.evidence:
(1) Vietnam currently does not import weapons from China. The main weapon supplier into Vietnam in the recent past has been Russia. Vietnam is now looking into diversifying its arsenal by Western weapons. 
(2) Vietnam deems Chinese weapons as lower in quality and due to the tense relations in history neither Vietnam nor China are interested in military business with each other.

Military.evidence:
At the end of 2023, China organized a joint military exercise Peace and Friendship with 5 ASEAN members. The drills focused mainly on anti-terrorism and anti-piracy activities. Representatives of the participating ASEAN countries including Vietnam claimed that the exercise did not signalize inclination to China but rather the effort to interconnect the region in terms of naval security.
Both defense ministers of two countries witnessed the signing of cooperation agreements between the agencies of their two ministries, which included a memorandum of understanding on military medical cooperation, an agreement on military staff education, and a memorandum of understanding on military education between Vietnam’s National Defense Academy and China’s Defense University.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence:
We have found mentions of several meetings on a very high level. (1) Defense Minister of Vietnam visiting China and participating in the Beijing Xiangshan forum. (2) High ranking officers meeting during the joint exercise in Guangdong province. (3) Several other meetings also took place, but below the one-star rank on the PRC side. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Few" and "Significant" rating.
on January 12,2024, Deputy Defense Minister Senior Lieutenant General Hoang Xuan Chien received Colonel Yu Qiang, Chinese Deputy Defense Attaché to Vietnam  at the Headquarters of the Ministry of National Defense.
Chinese defense minister meets Vietnamese counterpart
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: The extradition treaty between Vietnam and China, signed on Apr 7, 2015, is still valid. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Continuous cooperation on combating terrorism mentioned in the Joint Declaration after Xi Jinping's visit to Vietnam in Dec. 2023. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.

Law Enforcement.evidence: The Environmental Investigation Agency, an NGO, has determined that the Mong Cai Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Vietnam serves as a major entry point for ivory that is smuggled from China into Vietnam by organized criminal gangs, aided by corrupt customs and border control officers.

Law Enforcement.evidence: In Safeguard Defender's report, there is a mention of an overseas police service station under Nantong police jurisdiction established in Vietnam. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Vietnamese government is known for arbitrarily detaining people who engage in political activism criticizing the local establishment. Occasionally, the criticism of China can be perceived as a potential threat against the local government, e.g. criticism of the Chinese political system, criticism of Chinese investments and industrial zones in Vietnam. Even demontrations against the Chinese territorial claims in the South China Sea are not received well as they are considered a potentially destabilizing factor despite the fact that the Vietnamese government itself objects and denies the Chinese territorial claims.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Vietnam has ratified an extradition treaty with the PRC in 2020. The last traceable extradition case is from 2014.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Vietnam is the country where Hikvision, a Chinese manufacturer of visual surveillance equipment and monitoring systems, has the largest client base, with over 670,000 of its camera networks installed in the country.
